<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 890, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the mass \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) of a metre ruler using a balancing method.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 122]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 128, 816, 257]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 273, 532, 292]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 305, 146, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 305, 185, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 304, 870, 323]]<|/det|>
Place a load of mass \(M = 20 \text{g}\) with its centre at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark of the metre ruler.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 873, 369]]<|/det|>
Explain briefly how you make sure that the centre of the load is at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark. You may draw a diagram if it helps your explanation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 528, 917, 545]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 560, 917, 579]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 621, 180, 638]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 619, 920, 668]]<|/det|>
Place the metre ruler on the pivot. Adjust the position of the metre ruler on the pivot until the metre ruler is as near as possible to being balanced. Check that the position of the centre of the load remains at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 681, 848, 700]]<|/det|>
Record, in Table 1.1, the scale reading \(p\) on the ruler at the position of the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 713, 480, 731]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in Table 1.1:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 744, 683, 761]]<|/det|>
• The distance \(a\) between the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark and the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 758, 636, 777]]<|/det|>
Use your value of \(p\) and the equation \(a = p - 5.0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 775, 695, 793]]<|/det|>
• The distance \(b\) between the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark and the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 790, 648, 808]]<|/det|>
Use your value of \(p\) and the equation \(b = 50.0 - p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 821, 737, 839]]<|/det|>
Repeat this procedure for values of \(M = 40 \text{g}\), \(60 \text{g}\), \(80 \text{g}\) and \(100 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 836, 920, 855]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 730, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the reflection of light by two mirrors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 777, 120]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 435, 134]]<|/det|>
You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 141, 902, 604]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 616, 532, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 647, 144, 664]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 647, 819, 664]]<|/det|>
Mark and label a point \(\mathbf{F}\) approximately in the centre of your ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 663, 690, 680]]<|/det|>
Draw a \(5\mathrm{cm}\) long line \(\mathbf{FV}\), from point \(\mathbf{F}\), as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 678, 918, 711]]<|/det|>
Draw two lines, \(\mathbf{FG}\) and \(\mathbf{FE}\), each \(9\mathrm{cm}\) long and at \(50^{\circ}\) either side of \(\mathbf{FV}\), as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 710, 724, 727]]<|/det|>
Draw a normal to line \(\mathbf{FG}\), crossing \(\mathbf{FG}\) at a point \(\mathbf{N}\), \(6\mathrm{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{F}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 725, 608, 742]]<|/det|>
Label the lower end of the normal with the letter \(\mathbf{L}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 740, 848, 757]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(\mathbf{NA}\), as shown in Fig. 3.1, \(8\mathrm{cm}\) long and at an angle \(\theta_{1} = 15^{\circ}\) to \(\mathbf{NG}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 755, 920, 772]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 785, 144, 803]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 785, 920, 817]]<|/det|>
Place the plane mirrors on lines \(\mathbf{FG}\) and \(\mathbf{FE}\), with their reflecting surfaces facing inwards, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 816, 920, 833]]<|/det|>
Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), on line \(\mathbf{NA}\), a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 832, 460, 848]]<|/det|>
Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 846, 848, 863]]<|/det|>
View the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 861, 920, 893]]<|/det|>
Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), a suitable distance apart, so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), all appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 892, 460, 909]]<|/det|>
Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 908, 641, 925]]<|/det|>
Remove the mirrors and pins from the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 925, 920, 942]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 87, 895, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 737, 784, 757]]<|/det|>
Tie your ray-trace sheet into this booklet between pages 8 and 9.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 804, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the rate of cooling of hot water in a container which has a lid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which will enable him to compare the effect of lids of different thicknesses on the rate of cooling.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 398, 166]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 182, 233, 197]]<|/det|>
· a beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 198, 331, 214]]<|/det|>
· a supply of hot water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 532, 229]]<|/det|>
· insulating material from which lids can be cut.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 470, 259]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 274, 324, 290]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 457, 320]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 918, 351]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the rate of cooling can be determined

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 489, 367]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 397, 606, 413]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.
